text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx
Diabetes Daily \-- Researchers detail new data in Nutritional and Metabolic
Diseases and Conditions - Type 1 Diabetes. According to news reporting
originating from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, by NewsRx correspondents, research
stated, "This work aimed at testing the hypothesis that NOD/ShiLtJ mice (NOD)
recapitulate the cardiac disturbances observed on type 1 diabetes (T1D). NOD
mice were studied 4 weeks after the onset of hyperglycemia, and NOR/Lt mice
matched as control."

Funders for this research include Coordenacao de Aperfeicoamento de Pessoal de
Nivel Superior, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientifico e Tecnologico,
Fundacao Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo a Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro,
Instituto Nacional de Ciencia e Tecnologia de Biologia Estrutural e Bioimagem.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the Federal
University of Rio de Janeiro, "Cardiac function was evaluated by
echocardiography and electrocardiography (ECG). Action potentials (AP) and Ca
transients were evaluated at whole heart level. Heart mitochondrial function
was evaluated by high-resolution respirometry and HO release. NOD mice
presented a reduction in hearth weight. Mitochondrial oxygen fluxes and HO
release were similar between NOD and NOR mice. ECG revealed a QJ interval
prolongation in NOD mice. Furthermore, AP duration at 30% of repolarization
was increased, and it depicted slower Ca transient kinetics. NOD mice
presented greater number/severity of ventricular arrhythmias both in vivo and
in vitro."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "NOD mice evoked
cardiac electrical and calcium handling disturbances similar to the observed
in T1D. Graphical Abstract ."

For more information on this research see: NOD Mice Recapitulate the Cardiac
Disturbances Observed in Type 1 Diabetes. _Journal of Cardiovascular
Translational Research_ , 2020;():. _Journal of Cardiovascular Translational
Research_ can be contacted at: Springer, 233 Spring Street, New York, NY
10013, USA. (Springer - [www.springer.com](http://www.springer.com); Journal
of Cardiovascular Translational Research \-
<http://www.springerlink.com/content/1937-5387/>)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting O. Moreno-Loaiza, Laboratory of Cardioimmunology, Institute of
Biophysics Carlos Chagas Filho, Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Rio de
Janeiro, Brazil. Additional authors for this research include Y. Schleier,
M.M. Lopez Alarcon, E.G. Lopes Martins, B.C. Braga, I.P. Ramos, A. Galina and
E.H Medei.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1007/s12265-020-10039-y>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the _Journal of Cardiovascular Translational
Research_ is: Springer, 233 Spring Street, New York, NY 10013, USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Type 1 Diabetes Findings from Federal University of Rio de Janeiro Outlined (NOD Mice Recapitulate the Cardiac Disturbances Observed in Type 1 Diabetes): Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Type 1 Diabetes
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Diabetes Daily -- Researchers detail new data in Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Type 1 Diabetes. According to news reporting originating from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “This work aimed at testing the hypothesis that NOD/ShiLtJ mice (NOD) recapitulate the cardiac disturbances observed on type 1 diabetes (T1D). NOD mice were studied 4 weeks after the onset of hyperglycemia, and NOR/Lt mice matched as control.”

Funders for this research include Coordenacao de Aperfeicoamento de Pessoal de Nivel Superior, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientifico e Tecnologico, Fundacao Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo a Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Instituto Nacional de Ciencia e Tecnologia de Biologia Estrutural e Bioimagem.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, “Cardiac function was evaluated by echocardiography and electrocardiography (ECG). Action potentials (AP) and Ca transients were evaluated at whole heart level. Heart mitochondrial function was evaluated by high-resolution respirometry and HO release. NOD mice presented a reduction in hearth weight. Mitochondrial oxygen fluxes and HO release were similar between NOD and NOR mice. ECG revealed a QJ interval prolongation in NOD mice. Furthermore, AP duration at 30% of repolarization was increased, and it depicted slower Ca transient kinetics. NOD mice presented greater number/severity of ventricular arrhythmias both in vivo and in vitro.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “NOD mice evoked cardiac electrical and calcium handling disturbances similar to the observed in T1D. Graphical Abstract .”

For more information on this research see: NOD Mice Recapitulate the Cardiac Disturbances Observed in Type 1 Diabetes. Journal of Cardiovascular Translational Research, 2020;():. Journal of Cardiovascular Translational Research can be contacted at: Springer, 233 Spring Street, New York, NY 10013, USA. (Springer - www.springer.com; Journal of Cardiovascular Translational Research - http://www.springerlink.com/content/1937-5387/)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting O. Moreno-Loaiza, Laboratory of Cardioimmunology, Institute of Biophysics Carlos Chagas Filho, Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Additional authors for this research include Y. Schleier, M.M. Lopez Alarcon, E.G. Lopes Martins, B.C. Braga, I.P. Ramos, A. Galina and E.H Medei.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s12265-020-10039-y. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the Journal of Cardiovascular Translational Research is: Springer, 233 Spring Street, New York, NY 10013, USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
